Abstract

Federated Learning is an algorithm suited for training models on decentralized data, but the requirement of a central "server" node is a bottleneck. In this document, we first introduce the notion of Decentralized Federated Learning (DFL). We then perform various experiments on different setups, such as changing model aggregation frequency, switching from independent and identically distributed (IID) dataset partitioning to non-IID partitioning with partial global sharing, using different optimization methods across clients, and breaking models into segments with partial sharing. All experiments are run on the MNIST handwritten digits dataset. We observe that those altered training procedures are generally robust, albeit non-optimal. We also observe failures in training when the variance between model weights is too large. The open-source experiment code is accessible through GitHub111Code was uploaded at https://github.com/zhzhang2018/DecentralizedFL.

Keywordsâ€‚Federated Learning Â â‹…â‹…\cdot Distributed Learning Â â‹…â‹…\cdot Segmented Federated Learning Â â‹…â‹…\cdot small-world phenomenon

1 Introduction

Federated learning is an approach to learn on decentralized data, first proposed by McMahan etÂ al. (2017). In aims to provide privacy and safety benefits, federated learning has a distinct advantage over traditional data center-based training algorithm, thus has a huge potential in the Internet of Things (IoT) networks. The idea is to have a central server send a model to a batch of randomly selected devices (i.e., clients) with local data, then have each client perform a local update independently, and finally have the server aggregate all the updated client-side model parameters, and take their average as the model parameters in the next iteration. This procedure is named the Federated Averaging (FedAvg) algorithm.

Federated learning has been a rapidly growing research field ever since its introduction. The main challenges of federated learning are heterogeneous data distribution in real applications, the difficulty of collecting data, and theoretic analysis of convergence. Many recent research works have been adjusting the FedAvg algorithm and its variants for different applications and for reducing overall communication costsÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017; Sahu etÂ al., 2018; Wang etÂ al., 2020b; Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020). Many parts of the FedAvg algorithm could be adjusted for different situations, such as testing different aggregation methods (other than averaging), reduction of communication cost during aggregation, application considerations in real working environments, and so on.

Above federated learning algorithm requires a centralized model to maintain a global model over the network after aggregating information from other nodes. Considering of this drawback, distributed federated learning is proposed by some worksÂ (Lalitha etÂ al., 2019; Savazzi etÂ al., 2020; Taya etÂ al., 2021). Lalitha etÂ al. (2019) proposes a peer-to-peer distributed federated learning on graphs by performing a Bayesian update on the private belief vector thus form the public belief vector. Savazzi etÂ al. (2020) proposes a novel class of distributed federated learning based on the iteratively exchange of both model updates and gradients. Moreover, large scale massive networks are used to validate the algorithm. Recently, Taya etÂ al. (2021) presents a decentralized federated learning scheme called CMFD, the core idea of which is to aggregate the local prediction functions instead of parameters. These works show that switching from a centralized sharing scheme in FedAvg to a decentralized one can allow models to reach a consensus at the global minimum under some conditions, while avoiding communication bottleneck due to the server node.

This paper is organized as follows: Section 2 is the background of our problem. Section 3 presents the baseline we use for compare. Section 4 shows the effect of different dataset distribution. Section 5 presents the effect of different optimization methods. Section 6 is the analysis and simulation results of segmented federated learning with combination of small-world communication topology. Finally, Section 7 is the conclusion of our work and some future works.

The main contributions are stated as follows:

  1. 1.

    The effects of model aggregation frequency without initial weights is explored.

  2. 2.

    The effects of different dataset distribution, such as different dataset sizes, partially overlapping training data, skewed training data and differently normalized training data are presented.

  3. 3.

    The effects of different optimization methods are also tested on MNIST dataset.

  4. 4.

    Segmented Federated learning and small-world topology is combined and implemented.

  5. 5.

    Several unsolved problems and future works are proposed.

2 Background

In this section, we will first introduce the FedAvg algorithm, and the decentralized federated learning (DFL) adaptation. Then, we describe the neural network structure and computation tools used throughout the paper.

2.1 Decentralized Federated Learning

We attempt to solve the MNIST classification problem (LeCun etÂ al., 1998) with a general decentralized federated learning scheme, outlined in this section. For the following, we assume that GğºG is an undirected graph that describes client connectivity, and maintains strong connectivity over time. ğ’©iâ€‹(t)subscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğ‘¡\mathcal{N}_{i}(t) represents the nodes connected to client iğ‘–i at time tğ‘¡t. This algorithm is not a generalization to the centralized FedAvg algorithm. The FedAvg algorithm effectively uses a star graph GSsubscriptğºğ‘†G_{S} with K+1ğ¾1K+1 nodes, where the server node is the center. Lines 1-5 would still apply because the server node does not have its own local data. Lines 6-8 would be slightly different, in that the server does not put its own model in the averaging, and no client participates in the averaging, either. The FedAvg update rules would be:

Organizing the training procedure is much easier in this case. In addition, in FedAvg, the server only selects a subset of all the clients for each round. The aggregation algorithm always converges if the graph is connected and the weights are positiveÂ Mesbahi and Egerstedt (2010).

Observe that one key property of FedAvg is that all the clients start from the same model before starting each round of local training. The trained model could risk diverging if the starting weights are too far away from each other. This serves as an important thing to preserve when designing the parameters for the decentralized FL.

2.2 Methods

The network setup is based on the official PyTorch exampleÂ (PyTorch, ). The network consists of a 32-channel convolution layer, followed by another 64-channel convolution layer, both with a kernel size of 3 and followed by an activation of ReLU. After a 2Ã—2222\times 2 MaxPooling layer and a Dropout layer with probability 0.25 is a fully connected layer with 128 output values and ReLU activation. This is followed by another Dropout layer with probability 0.5, and then a second fully connected layer with 10 outputs. The outputs are turned into predictions for 10 classes through Softmax, and evaluated with negative log likelihood function against the correct label.

While the preliminary experiments in the following section are run on a local computer in Jupyter Notebook with a Python 3.8 kernel, the experiments in section 3 are run on PACE (2017).

3 Experiments to Establish Baselines

In this section, we first introduce parameters that need to be determined. Next, we present preliminary experiment results to show viability of DFL, and determine ranges of hyper-parameters used in the rest of the article.

3.1 Hyper-parameters in Decentralized Federated Learning

There are several values in the decentralized FedAvg process that are important to the training performance:

  • â€¢

    sğ‘ s, the number of iterations to execute the consensus protocol, so that clients reach the same model weights before starting another round of local update: If sğ‘ s is too large, then the averaging step would incur too much communication cost when models are already sufficiently close. If sğ‘ s is too small, then the client network would not be able to reach a consensus before making another round of update, and the model may diverge in the worst case. To make this parameter fall in an appropriate region, we set it as sÏµâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘ italic-Ïµğ‘¡s_{\epsilon}(t) where sÏµsubscriptğ‘ italic-Ïµs_{\epsilon} is defined as the least amount of iterations it would need for the entire networkâ€™s client models to reach consensus with error at most Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon between any pairâ€™s parameters. We place Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon at 0.1, and let s=minâ¡{100,sÏµ}ğ‘ 100subscriptğ‘ italic-Ïµs=\min\{100,s_{\epsilon}\} for this section. These values proved to be reasonable.

  • â€¢

    Eğ¸E, the amount of model updates performed throughout one epoch, between the model aggregation steps: This value also represents the inverse of model aggregation frequency. For example, if E=3ğ¸3E=3, then each client goes through its local dataset for 3 times before sharing their model parameters, and aggregation frequency is 1/3131/3 times per one pass of dataset. If E=0.5ğ¸0.5E=0.5, then the client only goes through half of the local training dataset before aggregation.

  • â€¢

    Î»ğœ†\lambda, communication network density : The client communication can be described by a graph GğºG where each client is a node, and each pair of communicating clients forms an edge, The network density can be described by the second eigenvalue of GğºGâ€™s Laplacian. A denser network generally has more connections and a higher magnitude of Î»ğœ†\lambda, and thus would have faster convergence rate âˆe|Î»|â€‹tproportional-toabsentsuperscriptğ‘’ğœ†ğ‘¡\propto e^{|\lambda|t} for the consensus protocol, Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0. This is covered in detail in subsection 6.3. Conversely, a less dense network has a slower convergence rate, and this rate is minimized when the network is a tree or a cycle. In this section, we mainly use a cyclic topology to simulate the behavior of model aggregation in a sparser network with slower convergence, as a semi-worse-case scenario.

In addition, the model construction and the training environment could also affect the performance. In this section, we fix most of those parameters mentioned above and in subsection 2.2 other than Eğ¸E. The goal is to find a good combination of those values, to serve as a baseline reference for experiments in other sections.

3.2 Preliminary Testing with Centralized Federated Learning

We first examine the performance of the original FedAvg algorithm. We run the centralized FedAvg algorithm from McMahan etÂ al. (2017), and follow the parameters in the original paper, where K=20ğ¾20K=20 clients and a central server train over the entire dataset. The dataset Dğ·D is randomly split into IID and mutually disjoint subsets D1,â€¦,DKsubscriptğ·1â€¦subscriptğ·ğ¾D_{1},...,D_{K}, and distributed across all clients. In addition, each epoch only updates half (C=0.5ğ¶0.5C=0.5) of all the clients, meaning that Câ€‹K=10ğ¶ğ¾10CK=10 clients participate each round of local model updates and parameter aggregation. To take care of the limited computational resources, and to reveal more interesting training behaviors across epochs, we reduce Eğ¸E from >10absent10>10 in the original paper to the range between 0.01 and 1. Batch size was also chosen to be B=10ğµ10B=10.

As a comparison, we also train a single model with the entire MNIST training dataset (|D|â‰œ60000â‰œğ·60000|D|\triangleq 60000 samples) as the baseline. The model reached 98.28% accuracy on the test set (6000 samples) after the first epoch.

The results show that the parameter choices for FedAvg could produce decent models. Server side model reaches 98% accuracy after around 20 epochs. Considering that there are K=20ğ¾20K=20 clients, Câ€‹Kâ€‹|D1|â€‹E=Câ€‹Kâ€‹|D|â€‹E/K=0.005â€‹|D|ğ¶ğ¾subscriptğ·1ğ¸ğ¶ğ¾ğ·ğ¸ğ¾0.005ğ·CK|D_{1}|E=CK|D|E/K=0.005|D| samples are used to update in each round, and 10%percent1010\% of all samples are used in this experiment to achieve 98% accuracy. After 100 rounds, the number of samples processed roughly equal to the size of the entire dataset, and the resulting test accuracy could compare with the 98.28% baseline accuracy.

3.3 Preliminary Testing with Decentralized Federated Learning

Next, we implement decentralized federated learning (DFL), where we choose K=10ğ¾10K=10 as a first step, so that the number of clients sharing the parameters each round would be the same as the Câ€‹Kğ¶ğ¾CK value in the experiment above. DFL requires an aggregation step instead of direct averaging, so we pick s=minâ¡(sÏµ,100)ğ‘ subscriptğ‘ italic-Ïµ100s=\min(s_{\epsilon},100) with error threshold Ïµ=0.1italic-Ïµ0.1\epsilon=0.1. Different from the methods in McMahan etÂ al. (2017), we switch to B=64ğµ64B=64 for faster training.

The dataset is partitioned evenly into Kğ¾K local sections for the clients, in an independent and identical distribution manner. The accuracy history on the test dataset after each training epoch tğ‘¡t is obtained as the prediction accuracy of the client with the lowest training loss lâ€‹(wiâ€‹(t))ğ‘™superscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘¡l(w^{i}(t)). All models start at the same initial weights. The behaviors are displayed in Table 1.

It appears that E=1ğ¸1E=1 reaches a good model quickly, while E=0.05ğ¸0.05E=0.05 would yield suboptimal performance. We also observe that training loss for E=0.005ğ¸0.005E=0.005 starts increasing after the 5th epoch, indicating model overfit. These preliminary experiments confirm that E=1ğ¸1E=1 and E=0.05ğ¸0.05E=0.05 are both reasonable choices in the DFL setup.

However, if we want to study the model behavior during training, we cannot let the models converge too quickly. E=1ğ¸1E=1 appears to be a good choice for training better-performing models, but E=0.05ğ¸0.05E=0.05 offers the opportunity to look closer into the model performance history over several hundreds of training epochs.

3.4 Effect of Model Aggregation Frequency without Uniform Initial Weights

In this section, we further observe the effect of Eğ¸E on model performance, but in an unconventional setup. In the standard federated learning setup, each client is supposed to have disjoint training datasets, for privacy concerns. Each training data should only be available to the client that hosts it, and the client is only supposed to share its model parameters without making the local sample somehow traceable by other clients. However, in an experimental setting, we could disregard this requirement, grant all clients access to the full or most part of the dataset, so that we can evaluate the robustness of the simple averaging aggregation step while excluding other factors.

Under this setup, we have an interesting observation: When E=1ğ¸1E=1, none of the client models is able to learn a good classification model when the initial model parameters happen to be completely random. The models quickly diverge, the test accuracy quickly drops to just above 10%, no better than random guesses. At the same time, the loss history for each client increases with tğ‘¡t, due to the unbounded nature of negative log-likelihood losses. The results in Table 2 shows the model behavior with different Eğ¸E values under this setup.

Converse to the observation in the previous section, a higher update frequency (smaller Eğ¸E) performs better in this situation.

The most possible explanation is that, when the aggregation became more frequent, the clientsâ€™ models would become less different after each epoch, and the model parameters would reach consensus faster. When E=0.005ğ¸0.005E=0.005, the models reach consensus at a suboptimal point first, and then could not advance forward. When E=0.05ğ¸0.05E=0.05 or E=1ğ¸1E=1, the models are trained for too long before aggregation, and the resulting centroid point is an even more suboptimal local minima.

The models are supposed to train better with more data available, especially with access to the entire dataset in this sectionâ€™s setup. Thus, we conclude that the federated learning method could be fragile without uniform weights across clients. In the following sections, we shall make sure all models start with a uniform set of weights or a close set of weights, unless otherwise specified.

4 Effects of Different Dataset Distributions

In the previous section, we have shown the effects of hyper-parameters on the federated learning when training on the MNIST dataset. In this section, as well as the following sections, we mostly settle down on a fixed combination of the hyper-parameters, and instead investigate the decentralized federated learning model behavior with other different adjustments.

In the following subsections, we present the performance of DFL when dataset partition across clients are not of the same sizes, not IID, or both. We also investigate the effect on performances with shared data between clients.

4.1 Different Dataset Sizes

To create clients with different dataset sizes, we draw samples from a Gaussian distribution x1:Kâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(0,Ïƒ2)similar-tosubscriptğ‘¥:1ğ¾ğ’©0superscriptğœ2x_{1:K}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma^{2}), and then randomly and uniformly draw Nisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–N_{i} samples for client iğ‘–i as its training data using the following equation:

Ni=minâ¡(|xi|â€‹|D|âˆ‘j=1K|xj|,B).subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ·superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ¾subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—ğµ\displaystyle N_{i}=\min\biggl{(}\dfrac{|x_{i}||D|}{\sum_{j=1}^{K}|x_{j}|},B\biggr{)}. (2)

The resulting dataset distribution for each client is kept IID by the uniform sampling.

To better describe the model performances, we define epsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘e_{p} as the number of epochs passed before the overall accuracy first exceeds p%percentğ‘p\%. We call p%percentğ‘p\% as the accuracy threshold with the corresponding epoch number, epsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘e_{p}. These values will be used as a quantifiable indication on model performance for the rest of the paper. As a preliminary test, we use different combinations of Kğ¾K and Ïƒğœ\sigma. The results are shown in Table 3. In all tests, the models are able to achieve 97% within 100 epochs, so we could conclude that DFL is robust against different dataset sizes when training in MNIST.

Note that, when Ïƒ2=10superscriptğœ210\sigma^{2}=10, the variance is high enough for up to 50% of the clients to only have B=64ğµ64B=64 data samples to start with. Most data are concentrated in a selected few clients. This unbalanced distribution facilitated the learning of these few with more training data, but their contributions are weakened during parameter sharing because they have the same weight as the ones with fewer training data. Thus, training is slower when Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} is higher, as expected. One way to overcome this is to use a weighted average sum, where the weight wisubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–w_{i} for the parameters of client iğ‘–i is proportional to Nisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–N_{i}, as proposed by Hu etÂ al. (2019).

4.2 Skewed Training Data

Zhao etÂ al. (2018) have already investigated the effect of skewed datasets on federated learning. In their paper, they partitioned the CIFAR-10 dataset, so that each client only has access to samples of the same label. For conveniency, we denote the dataset partition as:

D=â‹ƒm=110Dm;âˆ€mâ‰ n,Dmâˆ©Dn=âˆ…,formulae-sequenceğ·superscriptsubscriptğ‘š110subscriptğ·ğ‘šformulae-sequencefor-allğ‘šğ‘›subscriptğ·ğ‘šsubscriptğ·ğ‘›\displaystyle D=\bigcup_{m=1}^{10}D_{m};\ \ \forall m\neq n,D_{m}\cap D_{n}=\varnothing, (3)

where Dmsubscriptğ·ğ‘šD_{m} is the subset containing all data pairs with output labels as mğ‘šm. During partition, each client iğ‘–i is assigned a dataset D(i)âŠ‚Dcisuperscriptğ·ğ‘–subscriptğ·subscriptğ‘ğ‘–D^{(i)}\subset D_{c_{i}}, where integer ciâˆˆ[1,10]subscriptğ‘ğ‘–110c_{i}\in[1,10] indicates a specific label. As demonstrated in Zhao etÂ al. (2018), this assignment leads to poor performance on CIFAR-10, and could be alleviated by pre-allocating a shared global dataset containing uniform label distribution. Running the similar training procedure on MNIST give different results: The global model converges to an accuracy above 90%, but this accuracy is relatively poorer compared to the models trained with less skewed datasets.

Zhao etÂ al. (2018) proposed a coping mechanism by sharing a small packet of unskewed training data globally. The clients train on this global training data on top of their private datasets. This method is able to significantly improve the performance. In this paper, we slightly modify this procedure by only enabling pairwise sharing, in order to see if it could bring the same level of improvements.

We introduce the parameter Sâˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘†01S\in[0,1] to describe the amount of training data that one client shares with others. Again, we suppose each client iğ‘–i is assigned a partition D(i)superscriptğ·ğ‘–D^{(i)} on startup. Next, we perform the sharing step, where client iğ‘–i would share Sâ€‹|D(i)|ğ‘†superscriptğ·ğ‘–S|D^{(i)}| samples to all other clients. The shared samples are drawn uniformly, divided uniformly, and not necessarily the same for different clients. As such, each client jğ‘—j would receive SKâˆ’1â€‹|D(i)|ğ‘†ğ¾1superscriptğ·ğ‘–\dfrac{S}{K-1}|D^{(i)}| samples from iğ‘–i. After this step, each client iğ‘–i would have an expanded training dataset Dâ€²â£(i)superscriptğ·â€²ğ‘–D^{\prime(i)}, where:

|Dâ€²â£(i)|=|D(i)|+Sâ€‹âˆ‘j=1,jâ‰ iK|D(j)|superscriptğ·â€²ğ‘–superscriptğ·ğ‘–ğ‘†superscriptsubscriptformulae-sequenceğ‘—1ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ¾superscriptğ·ğ‘—\displaystyle|D^{\prime(i)}|=|D^{(i)}|+S\sum_{j=1,j\neq i}^{K}|D^{(j)}| (4)

Each client iğ‘–i would have shared a total of Sâ€‹|D(i)|ğ‘†superscriptğ·ğ‘–S|D^{(i)}| training samples to all other clients, and would have received Sâ€‹|D(j)|Kâˆ’1ğ‘†superscriptğ·ğ‘—ğ¾1\dfrac{S|D^{(j)}|}{K-1} samples from each client jğ‘—j. When S=0ğ‘†0S=0, no client shares any data to each other. On the other extreme, when S=1ğ‘†1S=1, all the clients use the same set of globally shared training data.

In the following, we compare the results using different optimizers provided by PyTorch with empirically-determined learning rates on a completely skewed dataset, with each label distributed to exactly one of the K=10ğ¾10K=10 clients. In addition, we investigate how sharing only a small percentage of the data samples can greatly alleviate the performance reduction. The learning rates (Table 4) are determined empirically to stabilize training and maximize performance, while keeping the training reasonably fast.

Figure 1(a) shows the average model performances with Sğ‘†S ranging from 0 to 1 under different optimizers. The accuracy values are obtained as the max average test accuracy across all clients within 500 epochs of training. The figure indicates that performances are dependent on optimizers. More importantly, the top performances does not differ by too much, as long as S>1%ğ‘†percent1S>1\%. Note that the horizontal axis is the total shared portions before training started. Because each client shared Sğ‘†S of its training data, the total shared portions would be Kâ‹…Sâ‹…ğ¾ğ‘†K\cdot S. Thus, S=1%ğ‘†percent1S=1\% corresponds to the 10âˆ’1superscript10110^{-1} mark on the horizontal axis.

In addition, we conduct further tests on models without same initial weights, shown in Figure 1(b). Without any sharing, the results from the previous sections have shown that models tend to fail at training. However, here it appears that the model training is stabilized with Sâ‰¥5%ğ‘†percent5S\geq 5\% for proper optimizers.

To investigate whether the observed convergence is affected by the higher model aggregation frequency at E=0.05ğ¸0.05E=0.05, we repeat the experiments using E=1ğ¸1E=1, and with same initial model weights. The results are similar to having E=0.05ğ¸0.05E=0.05, as shown in Figure 1(c). Note that these experiments are trained with only 50 epochs instead of 500, so that models at E=1ğ¸1E=1 are not trained with significantly more samples than did models at E=0.05ğ¸0.05E=0.05.

At this point, one may question what exactly is the difference between the effects caused by sharing data samples and by using less skewed data. We now try to combine both ideas. For simplicity, we again use K=10ğ¾10K=10 clients, and assign D(i)superscriptğ·ğ‘–D^{(i)} as the original training set for client iğ‘–i after partition. To describe the "skewed-ness" of the training data for model iğ‘–i, we define:

Uiâ‰œ|Diâˆ©D(i)||Di|â‰œsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘–subscriptğ·ğ‘–superscriptğ·ğ‘–subscriptğ·ğ‘–\displaystyle U_{i}\triangleq\dfrac{|D_{i}\cap D^{(i)}|}{|D_{i}|} (5)

This value is the percentage of the data with label iğ‘–i in D(i)superscriptğ·ğ‘–D^{(i)}. For example, in Figure 1, the dataset D(i)superscriptğ·ğ‘–D^{(i)} consists entirely of data with label iğ‘–i for each iğ‘–i, so Ui=1subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘–1U_{i}=1. This is the most unbalanced way of partitioning the training data.

In the following experiments, we assume Ui=Usubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘–ğ‘ˆU_{i}=U for all iğ‘–i, and we apply the data sharing procedure prior to training. Each client starts with partitioned dataset D(i)superscriptğ·ğ‘–D^{(i)} with skewedness Uisubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘–U_{i}. This means it contains Uâ€‹|Di|ğ‘ˆsubscriptğ·ğ‘–U|D_{i}| data samples with the label iğ‘–i, and (1âˆ’U)â€‹|Di|1ğ‘ˆsubscriptğ·ğ‘–(1-U)|D_{i}| data samples with other labels. We have |Di|=|D(i)|subscriptğ·ğ‘–superscriptğ·ğ‘–|D_{i}|=|D^{(i)}| for the dataset size.

Next, client iğ‘–i receives Sâ€‹|D(j)|Kâˆ’1ğ‘†superscriptğ·ğ‘—ğ¾1\dfrac{S|D^{(j)}|}{K-1} samples from each client jğ‘—j. The expected number of samples with label iğ‘–i in each of those datasets is thus Sâ€‹(1âˆ’U)â€‹|D(j)|(Kâˆ’1)2ğ‘†1ğ‘ˆsuperscriptğ·ğ‘—superscriptğ¾12\dfrac{S(1-U)|D^{(j)}|}{(K-1)^{2}}. After the sharing is complete, client iğ‘–i would have an expanded dataset Dâ€²â£(i)superscriptğ·â€²ğ‘–D^{\prime(i)} with size |Dâ€²â£(i)|=(1+S)â€‹|D(i)|superscriptğ·â€²ğ‘–1ğ‘†superscriptğ·ğ‘–|D^{\prime(i)}|=(1+S)|D^{(i)}|. The expected skewed-ness of this training set is thus:

Uâ€‹|Di|+âˆ‘j=1,jâ‰ iKSâ€‹(1âˆ’U)â€‹|Dj|(Kâˆ’1)2|Dâ€²â£(i)|=Uâ€‹(Kâˆ’1)+Sâ€‹(Uâˆ’1)(1+S)â€‹(Kâˆ’1)+Sâ€‹(1âˆ’U)(1+S)â€‹(Kâˆ’1)â€‹|D||Di|ğ‘ˆsubscriptğ·ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptformulae-sequenceğ‘—1ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ¾ğ‘†1ğ‘ˆsubscriptğ·ğ‘—superscriptğ¾12superscriptğ·â€²ğ‘–ğ‘ˆğ¾1ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ11ğ‘†ğ¾1ğ‘†1ğ‘ˆ1ğ‘†ğ¾1ğ·subscriptğ·ğ‘–\displaystyle\dfrac{U|D_{i}|+\sum_{j=1,j\neq i}^{K}\dfrac{S(1-U)|D_{j}|}{(K-1)^{2}}}{|D^{\prime(i)}|}=\dfrac{U(K-1)+S(U-1)}{(1+S)(K-1)}+\dfrac{S(1-U)}{(1+S)(K-1)}\dfrac{|D|}{|D_{i}|} (6)

We train the models with around 300 epochs and with E=1ğ¸1E=1 for a more practical update frequency. In addition, we record the epoch numbers e95,e98,e99subscriptğ‘’95subscriptğ‘’98subscriptğ‘’99e_{95},e_{98},e_{99} for accuracy thresholds 95%, 98%, and 99% respectively. The models all start with uniform initial weights. We test with the top-performing optimizers (Adam, Adadelta, RMSprop) with same learning rates from Table 4. The results are shown in Figure 2 and 3.

The general trend, as observed in Figure 2, is that the number of epochs it takes for the client models to reach a certain accuracy is larger if Sğ‘†S is smaller or Uisubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘–U_{i} is larger. This is most clearly illustrated by e99subscriptğ‘’99e_{99}. Because we train with E=1ğ¸1E=1, the shape of e98subscriptğ‘’98e_{98} and e95subscriptğ‘’95e_{95} has much less variation, but the trend is still visible. Figure 3(a-c) plots the same data, but in a different view that compares optimizers. In addition, Figure 3(d) plots the max average model accuracies, which mostly stay around 99% regardless of Sğ‘†S and Uğ‘ˆU. The only bad performance comes from when S=0ğ‘†0S=0 and U=1ğ‘ˆ1U=1, the same condition that leads to the worse performances in Zhao etÂ al. (2018).

It should be pointed out that other researchers have also come up with different ideas for reducing variance caused by skewed datasets, such as the SCAFFOLD algorithm proposed byÂ Karimireddy etÂ al. (2020).

4.3 Differently Normalized Training Data

In the previous experiments, the training data are pre-processed by normalization using the collective mean Î¼Msubscriptğœ‡ğ‘€\mu_{M} and variance ÏƒMsubscriptğœğ‘€\sigma_{M} computed from the entire training dataset, the same as the preprocessing in PyTorch . However, in applications where the data are truly distributed and private, it could be hard to obtain the correct global statistics of the training data. Instead, clients would have to rely on local data, and calculate normalization parameters from whatâ€™s available. Thus, in this section, we investigate if the training could be successful with different normalizations on the MNIST dataset. In particular, our experiments shift the normalization mean for each client by varying amounts. Î¼isubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–\mu_{i} is the normalization mean that each client uses on its raw data. For the first experiment, we define

Î¼1:4=Î¼Mâˆ’0.1,Î¼5:8=Î¼M+0.1,Î¼9:10=Î¼M+0.3formulae-sequencesubscriptğœ‡:14subscriptğœ‡ğ‘€0.1formulae-sequencesubscriptğœ‡:58subscriptğœ‡ğ‘€0.1subscriptğœ‡:910subscriptğœ‡ğ‘€0.3\displaystyle\mu_{1:4}=\mu_{M}-0.1,\;\mu_{5:8}=\mu_{M}+0.1,\;\mu_{9:10}=\mu_{M}+0.3 (7)

Figure 4(a-d) reports the model performance history in this setting by picking representative experiment results. The normalization parameters Î¼9:10subscriptğœ‡:910\mu_{9:10} for clients 9 and 10 were further from Î¼Msubscriptğœ‡ğ‘€\mu_{M}, and those models show worse performances. However, also note that the top accuracy for each model is lower than the accuracy seen in other experiments with uniform normalizations.

Further increasing the difference in mean values provided more drastic outcomes, as shown in Figure 4(e-f). While some models are able to achieve better performances, the clients with more normalization mean deviation perform much more poorly. This indicates that, while bad normalization parameters could hurt the performances (as shown by client 9 and 10), the majority of the clientsâ€™ models are robust against this with averaging.

Figure 5 presents the results from all experiments. When Sâ‰¥0.1ğ‘†0.1S\geq 0.1, the training is again stabilized, as demonstrated by the performance improvements. The maximum accuracy that each group of clients attained reveals the same trends that more sharing improves performance, and more normalization parameter deviation leads to worse performance.

Note that the values when S=0ğ‘†0S=0 are obtained from the last 10 epochs of training over 250 epochs, instead of from picking a historical max accuracy. This is because the max accuracy histories are noisy, and display large fluctuations.

5 Different Optimization Methods

Previously, we have seen that certain optimizer-learning rate pairs perform better than others in the same job, such as in Figure 1. In practice, we may deploy clients with different optimization setups, such as using different optimizers and learning rates, when it is not clear which combination would work best. For this section, we test the robustness of DFL, when clients use different optimization methods, but share the same optimization goal.

5.1 Different Learning Rates

In this section, we use Adadelta as the optimizer, with learning rate ranging from 0.001, 0.01, 0.1, 1, and 5 across K=10ğ¾10K=10 different clients. The training dataset is partitioned with U=0ğ‘ˆ0U=0, but sizes differed with Ïƒ2=0.7superscriptğœ20.7\sigma^{2}=0.7. In addition, to stabilize the training, we use data sharing with S=0.1ğ‘†0.1S=0.1. lâ€‹riğ‘™subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–lr_{i} is the learning rate of client iğ‘–i.

The results are shown in Figure 7, in which we try different kinds of learning rate combinations:

Figure 7(a) and (b) show the performance with E=0.05ğ¸0.05E=0.05 and E=1ğ¸1E=1, respectively. Those figures show that the clients could train successfully in these settings. In general, higher average learning rates lead to smaller epoch numbers and faster learning rate, but there is no clear-cut trend from the results.

Figure 7(c) presents results when we also combine different learning speeds for different clients. For example, if agent iğ‘–i has learning speed Ei=0.25subscriptğ¸ğ‘–0.25E_{i}=0.25 while others have speed E=0.05ğ¸0.05E=0.05, then client iğ‘–iâ€™s model gets updated 5 times more than other clients within one epoch. According to the figure, all the models are able to converge. However, from Figure 7(d), the setups with uniform aggregation frequencies would perform better. We also observe that slower aggregation frequency with E=1ğ¸1E=1 achieves better test accuracy, similar to what we observe in the preliminary experiments as well.

The results from the figures showed that, if the learning rates are conservative, then varying learning rate does not significantly affect the rate of training. However, we note that the presented results are from experiments that converge to good-performing models. If the learning rates are too large, the models risk diverging. This is what happened when E=1ğ¸1E=1 with learning rate distributions as lâ€‹r1:5=1ğ‘™subscriptğ‘Ÿ:151lr_{1:5}=1, lâ€‹r6:10=1.5ğ‘™subscriptğ‘Ÿ:6101.5lr_{6:10}=1.5, as shown by the lacking of data from E=1ğ¸1E=1 in Figure 7(d). Conversely, if the learning rates are too small, then model learning would be too slow to keep track of efficiently. This is tested, but not presented here.

5.2 Different optimization algorithms

In this section, we assign different optimizers for clients. We pick five optimizers included in PyTorch that are suited for classification tasks: Adam, Adagrad, Adadelta, RMSprop, and SGD. The learning rate for each optimizer is chosen empirically: 0.001, 0.01, 0.005, 0.0005, and 0.05, respectively. Note that these values are slightly different from what is in Table 4, but the orders of magnitudes are similar.

Again, we choose the training setup parameters to be E=0.05ğ¸0.05E=0.05, S=0.1ğ‘†0.1S=0.1, Ïƒ2=0.7superscriptğœ20.7\sigma^{2}=0.7, U=0ğ‘ˆ0U=0 with K=10ğ¾10K=10 clients. Figure 8 plots the maximum accuracy achieved by each of the combination that is tested. For each pair of optimizer combination that we test, we try 3 different ratios between the optimizers: 9 optimizers of one type plus 1 optimizer of another type; 7 of one type plus 3 of another; and 5 of each type. In addition, we test the performances of those setups under random initial model weights.

The results reveal that combining any two optimizing methods could lead to convergence to a satisfactory model for the MNIST classification problem, with or without uniform initial weights. However, the resulting accuracy values were lower than the baseline and the experiments done with uniform optimizers in previous sections.

In Figure 8(b), this is revealed by the grey surface that marks the 97% accuracy threshold. Note that none of the training where 5 clients used one optimizer and 5 used the other is able to reach an accuracy threshold of 97%. In comparison, experiments where one optimizer is used by the majority of the clients tends to have higher accuracy values.

The models with different optimizers and skewed training data partitions with U=1ğ‘ˆ1U=1 are still able to converge to a satisfactory global model, as long as Sâ‰¥1%ğ‘†percent1S\geq 1\%, as shown in FigureÂ 9. Those models are trained for 500 epochs for E=0.05ğ¸0.05E=0.05, and the optimizers are assigned to 5 clients each. It appears that combining different optimizers for skewed datasets lead to better performances than combining different optimizers on IID data partitions. These observations hint that, averaging the models trained using different optimizers could result in suboptimal performances when compared to baseline models, but might provide effective learning when the training dataset is also nonuniform. However, more experiments would be needed to verify this hypothesis.

6 Segmented Federated Learning

One common setup for all previous experiments is that they have to share the full set of weights each epoch. This can be costly in communication, especially in edge computing applications with less resources for communication, and scenarios with huge amount of devices. Thus, we are curious if itâ€™s feasible to reduce communication cost by only sharing a segment of the entire model to a selected few neighbors. In this section, we introduce existing work, then propose more segmentation options, and examine the results.

6.1 Existing Work

Hu etÂ al. (2019) test this idea by dividing the entire model Wisubscriptğ‘Šğ‘–W_{i} of a client iğ‘–i into several segments Wi1,â€¦,WiMsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘–1â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘–ğ‘€W_{i}^{1},...,W_{i}^{M}. In the aggregation step, each client polls segments from a fixed set of Rğ‘…R other clients, and performs weighted averaging according to each clientâ€™s dataset size. This procedure could be done in a gossip approach, to save communication cost while still giving convergence. However, it is unclear how they divided the model into "segments".

As a proof-of-concept, we treat each layer as a segment, and randomly pick R=3ğ‘…3R=3 clients out of the Kğ¾K clients for each segment. The training setup is the same as previous default setups, where models start from the same initial weights, are trained using the Adadelta optimizer with learning rate of 1, and use disjoint and IID partitions (S=0ğ‘†0S=0, U=0ğ‘ˆ0U=0). The results after 200 epochs is shown in Figure 6. The models can successfully converge to a set of parameters with sufficiently good performance with accuracy above 97%. For experiments with smaller Kğ¾K, the communication graph would be denser with fixed Rğ‘…R. We observe that denser graph requires less number of epochs for each accuracy threshold.

Figure 6(c-e) examines the model â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2} distance between clients. The model distances between all pairs of clients are examined, regardless of whether the clients are connected or not. The fact that the model distances are non-zero reveals that the model weights are not completely uniform at the end of each aggregation step, and at the start of each training epoch. This is expected in this segmented method, because the communication graph is directed, and is possible to have several components.

However, from the results, we see that the models donâ€™t have to be the same to get good performance. For example, as Wang etÂ al. (2020a) has observed, networks with permutations in parameters could give exactly the same performance.

In the next section, we formally define the Segmented Federated Learning approach in a decentralized manner.

6.2 Segment Units

The model used under current study, a simple convoluted neural network (CNN), can be described by a list of tensors with dimension up to 4D. 6.3 Connected graphs and small-world phenomenon

We use a graph G=(V,EG)ğºğ‘‰subscriptğ¸ğºG=(V,E_{G}) to represent the communication topology between clients, where V={1,â€¦,K}ğ‘‰1â€¦ğ¾V=\{1,...,K\}. If client iğ‘–i would receive a message containing the model parameters from client jğ‘—j, then a corresponding edge (j,i)âˆˆEGğ‘—ğ‘–subscriptğ¸ğº(j,i)\in E_{G} represents this connection. The consensus algorithm in DFL updates the model weights using the following expression:

Wiâ†1|ğ’©i|â€‹âˆ‘jâˆˆğ’©i(Wjâˆ’Wi),ğ’©iâ‰œ{j:(j,i)âˆˆEG}formulae-sequenceâ†superscriptğ‘Šğ‘–1subscriptğ’©ğ‘–subscriptğ‘—subscriptğ’©ğ‘–superscriptğ‘Šğ‘—superscriptğ‘Šğ‘–â‰œsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–conditional-setğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘–subscriptğ¸ğº\displaystyle W^{i}\leftarrow\frac{1}{|\mathcal{N}_{i}|}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}_{i}}(W^{j}-W^{i}),\ \ \mathcal{N}_{i}\triangleq\{j:(j,i)\in E_{G}\} (10)

In other words, each client updates its model by adding the average difference from its neighbors in the topology GğºG. This procedure is guaranteed to converge to the centroid of all clientsâ€™ models, as long as the undirected topology graph GğºG has only one component (or, equivalently, contains a spanning tree, or exists at least one path between each pair of clients). In addition, the rate of convergence is determined by the second eigenvalue Î»2,Gâ‰¥0subscriptğœ†2ğº0\lambda_{2,G}\geq 0 of GğºGâ€™s Laplacian LGsubscriptğ¿ğºL_{G}, which is the non-zero eigenvalue with the smallest magnitude for a connected graph. When using the consensus algorithm, there is a trade-off between having a dense and a sparse network. It is well-known that the rate of convergence is dominated by this eigenvalue. In general, a denser network has larger |Î»2,G|subscriptğœ†2ğº|\lambda_{2,G}|, and has faster convergence rate. On the other hand, however, a sparser network could require less communication between clients at each iteration. Thus, we observe a trade-off between less number of iterations and smaller communication cost per iteration.

Notice that the FedAvg algorithm is not easily generalized to the consensus algorithm. In the consensus algorithm, all clients update simultaneously in one iteration. In FedAvg, however, the aggregation is done in 2 iterations: Only the central client updates its model in the first iteration, using the average of all its neighbors but itself; then, the other clients get updated in the second iteration by directly replacing its model with the central clientâ€™s model. It achieves the same outcome as the consensus step in DFL, but the mechanism has a subtle difference.

Over two decades ago, Watts and Strogatz (1998) revealed the Small-World phenomenon in their seminal paper. The observation is that, starting from a circular graph topology where each node only connects to the few closest nodes ("local" connections), the eigenvalue Î»2subscriptğœ†2\lambda_{2} could be drastically increased by randomly rewiring some of those local connections to long-distance pairs. With enough rewiring, the convergence rate of the consensus algorithm could be increased without additional communication costs. For example, as shown in Figure 10, performing rewiring on the graph from 10(a) resulted in 10(b), which has the same number of edges but significantly higher Î»2subscriptğœ†2\lambda_{2} magnitude. 10(c) offers an example where the Î»2subscriptğœ†2\lambda_{2} could become even larger. However, in this topology, the clients would have to form connections with ones further away, instead of with local neighbors. In addition, the graph connections follow a delicate cyclic pattern, which is not practical.

Thus, the Small-World rewiring scheme allows us to maintain a sparse, realistic, yet effective topology. In the next section, we attempt to combine the segmented federated learning approach with the small-world topology to further reduce the communication cost.

6.4 Simulation Results of Segmented Federated Learning with Small-World Topology

In this segment, we present the experimental results from combining the segmented federated learning approach with Small-World communication topologies. Out of the possible smallest units, we would stick to using output channels (WLi,oâ€‹uâ€‹t,cijsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘Šğ‘—subscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘–W^{j}_{L_{i,out},c_{i}}), because:

  • â€¢

    Using layers (WLijsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘Šğ‘—subscriptğ¿ğ‘–W^{j}_{L_{i}}) should be equivalent to the existing work by Hu etÂ al. (2019);

  • â€¢

    Using kernels (kjâ€‹(i,ciâˆ’1,ci)superscriptğ‘˜ğ‘—ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–k^{j}(i,c_{i-1},c_{i})) proves to be taking too long in the simulation, and the result does not show successful training.

6.4.1 Segment Sharing with Clientwise Topology

In this section, we assume that the communication graph is undirected. All segment sharing are performed under the same Small-World client communication topology as Figure 10 shows, which is generated with k=2ğ‘˜2k=2 as the original number of neighbors per client, and p=0.5ğ‘0.5p=0.5 as the rewiring probability for each edge. Further, we define Pâ€‹Sâ€‹Sğ‘ƒğ‘†ğ‘†PSS as the portion of segment units shared per client. For example, if Pâ€‹Sâ€‹S=0.5ğ‘ƒğ‘†ğ‘†0.5PSS=0.5, then each client jğ‘—j would share half of all its segments WLi,oâ€‹uâ€‹t,cijsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘Šğ‘—subscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘–W^{j}_{L_{i,out},c_{i}} at each epoch. Pâ€‹Sâ€‹Sğ‘ƒğ‘†ğ‘†PSS is one of the parameters that are compared in Figure 11.

To aid further discussion, we also denote the set of indices of the chosen segments as Sâ€‹eâ€‹gâ€‹Iâ€‹nâ€‹djğ‘†ğ‘’ğ‘”ğ¼ğ‘›superscriptğ‘‘ğ‘—SegInd^{j}. Note that the segments are not picked layer by layer. Segments in all layers are considered together in this paper:

Figure 11 compares the performances of three different settings. They all simulate segment-wise aggregations, albeit in slightly different manners. The settingsâ€™ descriptions are listed below:

  1. 1.

    "Default" setting pre-determines the segment indices Sâ€‹eâ€‹gâ€‹Iâ€‹nâ€‹djğ‘†ğ‘’ğ‘”ğ¼ğ‘›superscriptğ‘‘ğ‘—SegInd^{j} that each client jğ‘—j would poll (receive) from others.     "Different segments per epoch" setting means that Sâ€‹eâ€‹gâ€‹Iâ€‹nâ€‹dtjğ‘†ğ‘’ğ‘”ğ¼ğ‘›subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘¡SegInd^{j}_{t} for client jğ‘—j is dependent on the epoch number tğ‘¡t: At each new epoch, the segment indices is randomly selected again. All the experiments are run with the default hyper-parameters: E=0.05,S=0,U=0formulae-sequenceğ¸0.05formulae-sequenceğ‘†0ğ‘ˆ0E=0.05,S=0,U=0, and trained with 200 epochs. They are run with 5 values of Pâ€‹Sâ€‹S={0.1,0.25,0.5,0.8,1.0}ğ‘ƒğ‘†ğ‘†0.10.250.50.81.0PSS=\{0.1,0.25,0.5,0.8,1.0\}. Figure 11(a-b) display the epoch numbers of different accuracy thresholds from e90subscriptğ‘’90e_{90} to e98.5subscriptğ‘’98.5e_{98.5} for each Pâ€‹Sâ€‹Sğ‘ƒğ‘†ğ‘†PSS value. Note that, if an accuracy threshold is never reached, then the corresponding value is not plotted. For example, the "Default" at Pâ€‹Sâ€‹S=0.1ğ‘ƒğ‘†ğ‘†0.1PSS=0.1 never reaches an accuracy over 97.5% within 200 epochs, so e98,e98.5subscriptğ‘’98subscriptğ‘’98.5e_{98},e_{98.5}, and e99subscriptğ‘’99e_{99} are missing from the plot. The maximum epoch number is at e97=100subscriptğ‘’97100e_{97}=100. Thus, even though it appears that the "Different segments" setting has the highest epoch numbers at Pâ€‹Sâ€‹S=0.1ğ‘ƒğ‘†ğ‘†0.1PSS=0.1, those correspond to accuracy thresholds that the other two settings never achieved within 200 epochs. The correct interpretation is not that "Different segments" setting takes the longest to reach accuracy thresholds, but that "Different segments" setting is the only one to reach those accuracy thresholds, and the other settings either could not reach them, or would have required much longer training. This is validated by Figure 11(c) as well.

From Figure 11, we observe that models with larger Pâ€‹Sâ€‹Sğ‘ƒğ‘†ğ‘†PSS values reached accuracy thresholds faster, and could reach a higher accuracy thresholds. This observation is true for all settings. Larger Pâ€‹Sâ€‹Sğ‘ƒğ‘†ğ‘†PSS means that more segments of the model would be at the same weights before each epoch starts, and the Pâ€‹Sâ€‹S=1ğ‘ƒğ‘†ğ‘†1PSS=1 case is exactly equivalent to the training setup in previous sections without segmenting.

Generally speaking, the performance of the "Different segments" setting is better than the "Default" setting. When clients poll different segments at each epoch, each part of the model would have a same chance of being aggregated in the long run. This helps make sure no segment of the client deviates from the global consensus too far.

Interestingly, the three settings end with different performances when Pâ€‹Sâ€‹S=1ğ‘ƒğ‘†ğ‘†1PSS=1. Theoretically, the full model weights are shared when Pâ€‹Sâ€‹S=1ğ‘ƒğ‘†ğ‘†1PSS=1, so the algorithm should be equivalent to FedAvg and to DFL. One possibility is that procedures that required randomness cause the discrepancies. Although each experiment shares the same random seed, different settings follow different procedures. For example, "Different Segments" setting would generate a random topology at each epoch, but "Default" setting would not have to. As a result, the model training procedure is not exactly the same between settings, even when starting with the same seeds.

From the performances above, we decide to only focus on "Default" and "Different segments per epoch" settings in the following section. They are different enough in implementation, and their performances are good enough. In addition, we limit the number of iterations per aggregation into s=minâ¡(20,sÏµ)ğ‘ 20subscriptğ‘ italic-Ïµs=\min(20,s_{\epsilon}) instead of s=minâ¡(100,sÏµ)ğ‘ 100subscriptğ‘ italic-Ïµs=\min(100,s_{\epsilon}) for the rest of the section. The reason is that 20 iterations has been enough for converging models to reach consensus.

Figure 14 is an additional plot showing the pairwise model distance history for a specific case where Pâ€‹Sâ€‹S=0.25ğ‘ƒğ‘†ğ‘†0.25PSS=0.25 and E=0.25ğ¸0.25E=0.25. The pairwise distances are increasing over time, even though the models are trained and aggregated normally. This is observed in all experiments shown in Figure 12 and 13 where Pâ€‹Sâ€‹S<1ğ‘ƒğ‘†ğ‘†1PSS<1. It is expected to see nonzero model distances from Figure 12(d). Without aggregation, any segment (i,ci)âˆ‰Sâ€‹eâ€‹gâ€‹Iâ€‹nâ€‹djğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘†ğ‘’ğ‘”ğ¼ğ‘›superscriptğ‘‘ğ‘—(i,c_{i})\notin SegInd^{j} would not be aggregated, and would not become uniform across clients. In fact, different segment weights could demonstrate similar behaviors, as observed by Wang etÂ al. (2020a).

On the other hand, the nonzero distances in Figure 13(d) could be explained differently, while it should be expected that all the segments are polled by at least some client, i.e.,

â‹ƒj=1,â€¦,KSâ€‹eâ€‹gâ€‹Iâ€‹nâ€‹dj=â‹ƒi=1,â€¦,l{(i,ci):1â‰¤ciâ‰¤Ci}subscriptğ‘—1â€¦ğ¾ğ‘†ğ‘’ğ‘”ğ¼ğ‘›superscriptğ‘‘ğ‘—subscriptğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘™conditional-setğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ¶ğ‘–\displaystyle\bigcup_{j=1,...,K}SegInd^{j}=\bigcup_{i=1,...,l}\{(i,c_{i}):1\leq c_{i}\leq C_{i}\} (12)

Those clients that share one segment only constitute a subset of the client-wise Small-World topology. The aggregation topology for each segment could contain more than 1 components, where different components never aggregate with clients from each other. This, again, explains why some, if not most, segments would not contain the same weights at each epoch. Again, it is known that models could give similar behaviors without the same set of weights. Hence, we again see model distances increasing over time due to segment differences over individual training without aggregation, while the models are still giving similar performances.

Figure 15 offers a view of segment-wise distance history. Figure 15(a) shows the distance over all aggregation iterations, where the distances between shared segments quickly drop to 0, while the others remain the same. Similarly, Figure 15(b) and Figure 15(c) shows the distances at the start and end of each epoch. The distances between shared segments increase a bit during individual training, but then dropped to 0. The distances between segments that are not shared would remain the same.

6.4.3 Segment-wise Sharing Topologies

Instead of relying on the original Small-world communication topology between clients, we propose aggregation with segment-wise topologies, as an attempt to guarantee consensus among aggregated segments. Two methods are developed and detailed below.

"Different topology per segment" setting: Here, we randomly generate a small-world sharing topology graph Gi,cisubscriptğºğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–G_{i,c_{i}} for each segment WLi,oâ€‹uâ€‹t,cisubscriptğ‘Šsubscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘–W_{L_{i},out,c_{i}} with index (i,ci)ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–(i,c_{i}). Each client jğ‘—j still keeps a set of segment index Sâ€‹eâ€‹gâ€‹Iâ€‹nâ€‹djğ‘†ğ‘’ğ‘”ğ¼ğ‘›superscriptğ‘‘ğ‘—SegInd^{j} that it shares with others at each aggregation iteration, and its size is still |Sâ€‹eâ€‹gâ€‹Iâ€‹nâ€‹dj|=Pâ€‹Sâ€‹Sâ‹…âˆ‘i=1lCiğ‘†ğ‘’ğ‘”ğ¼ğ‘›superscriptğ‘‘ğ‘—â‹…ğ‘ƒğ‘†ğ‘†superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘™subscriptğ¶ğ‘–|SegInd^{j}|=PSS\cdot\sum_{i=1}^{l}C_{i}. Similar to "Default" setting, we still guarantee Sâ€‹eâ€‹gâ€‹Iâ€‹nâ€‹dj1=Sâ€‹eâ€‹gâ€‹Iâ€‹nâ€‹dj2ğ‘†ğ‘’ğ‘”ğ¼ğ‘›superscriptğ‘‘subscriptğ‘—1ğ‘†ğ‘’ğ‘”ğ¼ğ‘›superscriptğ‘‘subscriptğ‘—2SegInd^{j_{1}}=SegInd^{j_{2}} for any j1â‰ j2subscriptğ‘—1subscriptğ‘—2j_{1}\neq j_{2}. Figure 16 includes results that compare the previous two settings and this setting.
"Directed, Different segments and topology" setting: Here, each segment WLi,oâ€‹uâ€‹t,cisubscriptğ‘Šsubscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘–W_{L_{i},out,c_{i}} still follows a small-world connection topology Gi,ci(t)superscriptsubscriptğºğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘¡G_{i,c_{i}}^{(t)}. However, to simulate the stochastic factors in real application that could affect the communication, this small-world connection topology is randomly formed at each epoch tğ‘¡t. This is to simulate an application where each client jğ‘—j does not know which segmentâ€™s message would arrive first during polling. To deal with this uncertainty with less communication cost, it stops polling from other clients once it has received Pâ€‹Sâ€‹Sâ‹…âˆ‘i=1lCiâ‹…ğ‘ƒğ‘†ğ‘†superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘™subscriptğ¶ğ‘–PSS\cdot\sum_{i=1}^{l}C_{i} segments in total. As a result, the effective communication graph for each segment at each time would be different. For simplicity, we only change the topology Gi,ci(t)subscriptsuperscriptğºğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–G^{(t)}_{i,c_{i}} at the start of each aggregation, and assume that all following iterations would use the same topology. The following describes this procedure for client jğ‘—j:

We assume that each message regarding WLi,oâ€‹uâ€‹t,cijsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘Šğ‘—subscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘–W^{j}_{L_{i},out,c_{i}} would also contain a list of existing edges for this segment, so that the client could estimate if the communication topology has already become a complete graph. The time it takes for each segmentâ€™s message to reach client jğ‘—j is fully stochastic, so the set of segments that are aggregated for jğ‘—j, and the set of clients whose segment weights are used during the aggregation for each segment is also fully random. In simulation, however, we could simplify the procedure as follows:

Notice that, unlike in the other settings, this procedure does not have guarantee of an undirected (bidirectional) update graph for each segment. Thus, it would be hard to guarantee consensus convergence in this setting. This could be tackled with future research efforts.

In Figure 16, we compare the performances of all 4 settings. In Figure 16(a-b), the general trend is that "Different segments" setting has the fastest rate to reach certain accuracy thresholds; the settings with segment-wise topology graphs often has similar performances with each other. On the other hand, Figure 16(c) reveals that all settings have very similar performances in terms of peak accuracy, and (d) shows that the model distance history for each setting is also similar.

According to Figure 12(d) and Figure 13(d), as Eğ¸E increases, the model distance would increase as well. Thus, if Figure 16(d) are showing the results with E=0.05ğ¸0.05E=0.05 from all settings, then the distance ranges from settings with client-wise topologies would have been even smaller than the settings with segment-wise topologies. Thus, the segment-wise sharing settings achieve similar performances, proving that they are viable. However, once again, not all segments are aggregated when Pâ€‹Sâ€‹S<1ğ‘ƒğ‘†ğ‘†1PSS<1. This explains why the model distances are still nonzero.

6.4.4 Practicality Analysis and Conclusions

To evaluate the effect of the different segmented federated learning approaches mentioned above, we have documented the communication costs of the procedure, represented simply as the combined sizes of shared segments at each epoch for now. The results are shown in Figure 17, where the y-axis unit is in millions of floats. The figure compares the 4 settings defined in previous sections (with at most 20 aggregation iterations). In addition, it included the three test scenarios from Figure 11 (with at most 100 aggregation iterations).

As expected, larger Pâ€‹Sâ€‹Sğ‘ƒğ‘†ğ‘†PSS values resulted in larger communication costs, but more factors come into play. Between the first four settings, at each Pâ€‹Sâ€‹Sğ‘ƒğ‘†ğ‘†PSS value, the amount of segments being shared are the same. In addition, the number of edges in communication graphs should also be the same, because they followed the same Small-World topology generation procedure. Thus, the factor that caused different communication costs should be the amount of iterations required to reach consensus.

The communication cost difference between the complete graph setting and the rest in Figure 17 demonstrates the trade-off between denser network and higher communication cost well. The complete graph network requires relatively fewer iterations to converge than small-world networks, thanks to its high density. However, as Pâ€‹Sâ€‹Sğ‘ƒğ‘†ğ‘†PSS increases, the amount of messages passed within a complete graph grows faster than the amount for Small-World graphs. As a result, the complete graph communication cost exceeds the other settings before Pâ€‹Sâ€‹S=0.5ğ‘ƒğ‘†ğ‘†0.5PSS=0.5. The additional cost due to higher density exceeded the savings by having a faster convergence rate.

The settings using fixed topology end up with 3 times less communication cost than the ones using segment-wise topology, even when not considering the extra overhead generated when determining the communication topology for each segment. In real applications, the segment-wise small-world option would require more communication to verify the connectivity of the graph, so the communication costs would be even larger. In addition, from a programming perspective, the simulation runtime of segmented approaches is significantly longer than the default setting. While this could be a result of inefficient implementation, we still conclude that segmented federated learning with channels as the basic unit is currently impractical.

7 Conclusion and Future Works

In conclusion, our experiments show that DFL demonstrates robustness in training, even with different adjustments to the training scheme. In this section, we summarize the takeaways of each section, and list future directions.

7.1 Different Dataset Settings

We have observed that clients could share a small portion of training data with each other to stabilize training, especially if the training data is skewed between clients. In addition, models could still fit the training data well with varying normalization values and/or loss functions, provided that they are not too off from the true value.

Future work could verify if the same behavior can be observed from other benchmark datasets. In addition, one could apply the learning scheme to real-world distributed systems where clients have heterogeneous beliefs based on local observations, such as having different dataset statistics.

One may also consider testing the DFL robustness by combining different normalization parameters with skewed dataset partitions. In a preliminary experiment, we calculated the normalization parameters Î¼isubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–\mu_{i} based on the partitioned dataset Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i} for each client iğ‘–i. After training with Adam optimizer with learning rate at 0.001 for 50 epochs, the global model accuracy maxed out at 98% with S=5%ğ‘†percent5S=5\%. Meanwhile, the accuracy was at most 86% when S=0ğ‘†0S=0. This indicates that DFL might be robust in this scenario, but more tests are needed.

7.2 Different Optimization Methods

In our experiments, we have explored different combinations of learning rates and optimizers. While we have observed suboptimal performances from both scenarios, we have also seen that the DFL scheme is robust enough to arrive at working models with conservatively modified learning rates. In addition, we observe a slightly better performance when different optimizers are simultaneously applied to skewed datasets.

We observe that the skewed dataset experiment draws certain similarities with the notion of ensemble learning. In ensemble learning, multiple models are trained with varying objectives, and the final prediction is determined through a weighted vote from all models (Dietterich, 2000). In our skewed dataset experiment, each client holds a model specialized with a certain training data distribution, and models are trained with different optimizing methods. However, instead of combining their outputs through a weighted sum, the DFL training scheme directly takes the (weighted) average of the model parameters. Both methods feature a distributed set of models, and a combination of predictions from all those models, albeit in different implementation methods. Future work could study their connections and differences in more detail, as well as verify if the observations would still hold in other benchmark datasets and training tasks.

7.3 Segmented Federated Learning

First and foremost, works in the future should check if the observations described above would still hold true for a task that is harder to train on. For example, using a simpler model with fewer parameters to learn MNIST classification, or using the same model in this paper for CIFAR-10 classification, would both prolong the learning process, and allow us to "zoom in" the graphs over epochs further. In addition, more complex benchmark tests would allow for less frequent model aggregations - as we have observed, less frequent aggregation would yield better and faster performances, but the current model cannot afford to do so if the accuracy reaches 99% within the first epoch.

In addition, it is important to derive and analyze theoretical results of the methods above, if feasible. By finding theoretical bounds of the training procedure, or finding equivalencies between experiments listed above, the testing could become less complicated.

The segmentation procedure requires optimizing the current implementation, as well. The smaller the segments, the more of them needs to be shared, and this results in larger overhead costs. Instead of reducing segment sizes, perhaps a better way is to reduce the resolution of the shared parameters, so that each clientâ€™s shared parameters could be represented with much less bits - for example, Reisizadeh etÂ al. (2020) proposed a variation algorithm, FedPAQ, that aimed at reducing communication cost by reducing the update frequency and quantizing the update process.

Alternatively, the communication cost could be reduced by limiting the parameter structures. For example, if we approach the image classification task not with a CNN model, but with a graphical model such as a Markov Random Field, then the number of shared parameters could be reduced to the graph topology and the edge potentials. Past work regarding consensus with Bayesian Networks also exist in Pena (2011). With the rise of interest in Graphical Neural Networks (GNN), there is much potential for this idea.

Possible future steps include sharing simplified models with similar performances, using ideas of transfer learning in decentralized ways, training Spars Convolutional Neural Networks (SCNN, developed byÂ Liu etÂ al. (2015)) to reduce cost, etc. Some researchers have also discovered that models could grow further apart (measured by mutual information) while still increasing their parametersâ€™ correlations, thus showing us a different explanation to why the whole model distances are growing with each epochÂ (Xiao etÂ al., 2020).

7.4 Other topics

If we want it to work on a directed graph, then we might have to use training schemes like push-sum, as mentioned by Nedic and Olshevsky (2014); Olshevsky etÂ al. (2018) to guarantee convergence. One work that combines Federated Learning with push sum scheme is He etÂ al. (2020).

One other idea is to have each client solve one particular classification problem (i.e. hold 10 clients, and each client iğ‘–i is responsible for training a set of parameters wisubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–w_{i} that predicts the probability that the given image belongs to class iğ‘–i), and see if this still fulfills the decentralized optimization problem definition. One may also consider using the ADMM procedure, as outlined byÂ Boyd etÂ al. (2011), for federated learningÂ (Elgabli etÂ al., 2020).

Another topic of interest is checking the effect of periodically applying random noises to some of the models, as a way to "nudge" models off from possible local minima. With multiple clients sharing their parameters in the federated learning framework, it could be possible that this model would encourage some of the clients to find a successful alternate direction. This idea could also be implemented by giving different momentum values for different clients, where clients with higher momentum values during optimization would tend to explore more, while clients with lower momentum would hold them back at each update step to prevent from possible divergence.

Federated Learning could also apply in other settings. For example, consider Federated Reinforcement LearningÂ (Zhuo etÂ al., 2019) - naturally, it would suit a multi-agent setup. Agents could communicate each otherâ€™s findings through shared parameters, and converge to certain behavioral models. One other way to adapt this is to set it as a parallel training procedure, similar to ensemble learning, where multiple agents learn in the same environment with different parameters and hyper-parameters, and we try to locate one good model from them.
